error.signature: ERROR: <package>.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.

verdict.summary: The wheel file was built for a different platform (OS, architecture, or Python implementation). Common when downloading wheels from another machine, mixing x86_64/aarch64, or using glibc wheels on musl (Alpine).

dead_ends.action: Rename the wheel file to match current platform tags
dead_ends.why_fails: The wheel contains compiled binaries for the original platform; renaming does not recompile them and will cause runtime crashes
Force-reinstall does not override platform compatibility checks; pip still rejects the wheel

workarounds.action: Install directly from PyPI to get the correct platform wheel
workarounds.how: pip install <package> (without specifying a local wheel file)
workarounds.condition: when a compatible wheel exists on PyPI

workarounds.action: Build from source for the current platform
Check compatible tags and download the right wheel: pip debug --verbose
workarounds.how: Run pip debug --verbose to see supported tags, then download a wheel matching one of those tags

leads_to.condition: when no compatible wheel exists for the platform at all

preceded_by.condition: when user downloads wheel from wrong platform after not finding it normally

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Platform-mismatch means a wheel exists but for the wrong platform; no-binary means no prebuilt wheel exists at all for any compatible platform
